newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Reps reoffer bill to curb hospital spa bonds.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Reps reoffer bill to curb hospital spa bonds.

text.p: Two U.S. House members reintroduced legislation this week that would bar tax-exempt financing for fitness spas run by nonprofit hospitals.
Jerry Kleczka, D-Wis., and James Sensenbrenner, R-Wis., originally offered the "Taxpayer Bond Fairness Act" in June 1996, but the U.S. House Ways and Means Committee did not act on the measure.
Kleczka said last year that the bill would close a loophole that allows hospitals to use "taxpayer-supported" bond offerings for a commercial business.

The 1996 bill came on the heels of another controversial measure introduced in June 1996 by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., that would eliminate tax-exempt financing for professional sports stadiums.

Moynihan's original bill set a June 14, 1996, effective date, but he later agreed to delay it. An aide said this week he probably will reintroduce his measure on Jan 21 with an effective date of whenever the Senate Finance Committee votes on the measure.

Simultaneously, Moynihan will reoffer a bill that would eliminate a federal curb on bond issuance that the senator says denies tax-exempt financing to large, private research institutions, an aide said.
It is unclear whether Kleczka and Sensenbrenner would delay the July 12, 1996, effective date, that appeared in last year's bill.
Their bill also would target fitness spas run by nonprofit hospitals as "unrelated businesses," which would make their profits subject to federal income taxes.
Kleczka registered strong opposition at a hearing last year in his state to issuance of tax-exempt bonds for construction of a proposed spa and fitness center for Waukesha Memorial Hospital.
He told the Wisconsin Health and Educational Facilities Authority the hospital wanted a center with steam rooms, whirlpools, massage and spa services, a restaurant and "other amenities."
